Emotional_TRUSTS.source: Lord Canterville felt it his duty to mention the fact to Mr. Otis, when they came to discuss terms.
Mrs. Otis had never fallen into this error. She had a magnificent constitution, and a really wonderful amount of animal spirits.
Miss Virginia E. Otis was a little girl of fifteen, lithe and lovely as a fawn, and wi th a fine freedom in her large blue eyes.

After Virginia came the twins, who were usually called "The Stars and Stripes" as they were always getting swished. They were delightful boys, and with the exception of the worthy Minister the only true republicans of the family.
Mrs. Otis, at Lady Canterville's earnest request, had consented to keep on Mrs. Umney in her former position.
Virginia was filled with pity, and determined to try and comfort him.
The little Duke of Cheshire, who was perfectly frantic with anxiety, begged hard to be allowed to go too, but Mr. Otis would not allow him, as he was afraid there might be a scuffle.
The Minister could not help smiling at the handsome young scapegrace, and was a good deal touched at his devotion to Virginia
Poor Sir Simon! I owe him a great deal. Yes, don't laugh, Cecil, I really do. He made me see what Life is, and what Death signifies, and why Love is stronger than both.

Interaction_APPEARED_TOGETHER.context: Discussing the sale of Canterville Chase

Event_AFFECTED_BY.impact: Felt it his duty to mention the fact to Mr. Otis that the place was haunted.
Noticed a bloodstain in the library.
Removed the bloodstain with Pinkerton's Champion Stain Remover, causing a storm and Mrs. Umney to faint.
Fainted after Washington Otis removed the bloodstain.
Warned Mr. Otis to beware of some trouble coming to the house.
Humiliated by the Otis family's reactions to his attempts to scare them, including being offered lubricant and having pillows thrown at him.
